section.title: Introduction to Simal
section.p: Simal aims to be a community development and support tool. It will facilitate relationships between projects and contributors to those projects. It will enable users to quickly identify groups of projects and individuals with whom they share a common goal.

In its simplest form, Simal will be a project catalogue. It will enable users of the catalogue to search and filter data along a great many data axis. As the tool matures both manual and semi-automated features for discovering projects and people in specific areas of interest will be added. In order to do this it will build upon growing interest in the semantic web and web 2.0 technologies.

Simal will be an open source project, hosted on Google Code. It is expected to be released under the Apache License Version 2.0. This licence was chosen as we believe that it provides the most flexibility for downstream projects wishing to utilise the Simal outputs.

section.title: Governance Model
section.p: Simal's governance model will be community-based consensus, similar to that found within The Apache Software Foundation projects. Decisions about the future of the project will be made through discussion with all members of the community, from the newest user to the most experienced contributor. When consensus cannot be easily gained through discussion a voting procedure will be used. Binding votes are awarded to those who demonstrate an understanding of the project's objectives and governance model through a positive involvement with the project community.

section.title: Why is OSS Watch leading Simal?
section.p: OSS Watch is a JISC-funded development service which promotes awareness and understanding of the legal, social, technical and economic issues that arise when educational institutions engage with free and open source software. Within this remit OSS Watch provides guidance to projects wishing to create open source projects. It is useful for OSS Watch to illustrate key aspects of consensus-based open source software development in practice. Simal will serve both as opportunity for OSS Watch to explore the practicialities of this form of open source development, while at the same time providing an exemplar for JISC projects with respect to typical governance models, community building, release management, quality assurance, user support and documentation. It will involve a commitment of approximately 0.1 FTE of effort over 4 months to reach public launch.

However, Simal is no mere project template. OSS Watch fully intend to deploy the outputs from Simal, i.e. a project catalogue, in order to serve as a means of building community relationships between JISC development projects. This is a task OSS Watch had set itself previously and Simal will help fulfil it. Simal itself, of course, draws upon significant work done by other open source projects, e.g. Apache Forrest, Apache Wicket, Databinder and Hibernate, and its own entry in the catalogue will reflect this.
To summarize, the benefits to OSS Watch in leading Simal are:

ul.li: ongoing practical engagement for OSS Watch team members in a consensus-based open source development project
learning points reflected back to JISC projects as advice and guidance
project catalogue of JISC development projects to be deployed on OSS Watch website

section.title: What benefit will Simal provide to the JISC?
section.p: The most immediate and obvious benefit to JISC Development is the provision of a project template that other JISC-funded projects may freely adopt and adapt as their individual needs demand. OSS Watch already provides consultation support to projects. The Simal documentation set will allow this consultation to be more guided and more effective. These templates will, we hope, be living documents that will over time grow to reflect the diverse needs of JISC projects.

A further practical benefit to JISC projects will be the opportunity to use the Simal catalogue tool for their own needs. For example, JISC CETIS maintains an e-learning project catalogue. The adoption of Simal will remove the need to duplicate efforts between OSS Watch and JISC CETIS. Similarly, individual projects will be able to publish more focused catalogues relating to their local communities without needing to expend considerable energy in maintaining those catalogues.

Simal can also be used to increase the wider awareness of JISC-funded projects without additional overhead on individual projects. This is achieved through a mechanism that allows projects to submit their publicly available data to third party catalogues with very little additional effort. Individual projects maintain a single machine readable file for all catalogue entries, a DOAP file. This file is stored on the project's own web server and conforms to a standard format reconised by other catalogue systems such as O'Reilly's CodeZoo. Modifications to all catalogues featuring the project can be made by editing this single locally managed file. This reduction in overhead in maintaining catalogue entries results in more accurate and more widespread data about JISC-funded projects.

The JISC could benefit from this increased data accuracy and availability directly. For example, the JISC could use this data to create the "What We Do" section of the JISC website. In the future, the Simal system could be used to provide data for the proposed PIMS application, thus minimising the effort required by programme managers in ensuring the PIM data is accurate.

Finally, Simal is able to collate and link to data in existing JISC databases. For example, it can utilise and relate to information provided in the e-framework database and the standards catalogue. As such Simal could be used to draw valuable data from disparate projects within the JISC and present it in a uniform, accurate and, where approprite, secure way.
To summarize, the benefits to JISC from the Simal project are:

ul.li: consensus-based project templates as an adaptable model for other JISC projects
JISC projects able to maintain their own Simal catalogues
projects able to spread news of their project through project-maintained DOAP file
possible use of project catalogue on JISC website

section.title: What benefit will Simal bring to the OUCS?
section.p: Simal will be clearly identified on Google Code as an OSS Watch project. OSS Watch is consistently identified as a JISC-funded project hosted by Oxford University Computing Services. OUCS will thus gain recognition through this effort.

OUCS could also use the Simal output to collate information about OUCS projects whether internal or externally funded. Internal project teams can use it to discover related projects, individuals and communities both inside and outside of OUCS. In general, Simal will facilitate a more informed management of internal projects.

The framework will be designed to be extensible so, for example, it could be extended to formally support the data required in OUCS' internal "light touch" project management methodology. By customising Simal in this way, OUCS will be able to collate this valuable information in a more useful human and machine readable form. This paves the way for more effective reuse of the knowledge acquired within OUCS projects.
To summarize, the benefits to OUCS from the Simal project are:

ul.li: associated branding on a Google Code project
possible use to collate information about OUCS projects
possible extension of Simal to accommodate data from OUCS "light touch" project management methodology
